sp.l: What earthquake shakes my heart,
With what a speed she flew into his arms!

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.l: Some power that hearkens to the prayer of virgins,
Has been distilled to pity at my fortunes;
And made Evadne happy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now my longing that was grown big,
Is with your sight delivered of a joy,
That will become a giant; and overcome me.
Welcome, thrice welcome brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, her brother! Fortune has bound me
so much in their debts, I must despair to pay 'em:
Twice has my life been by these twins of goodness
Plucked from the hand of death; that fatal enmity
Between our houses here shall end,
Though my father at his death commanded me
To eternity of hatred:
What tie binds stronger than reprieve from death?
Come hither friend; now brother, take her,
Thou hast been a noble tailor.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Be moderate my joys, do not o'er whelm me
Here take Aurelia, may you live happy:
Oh Antonio this, this was the cause of my disguise;
Sebastine could not win Evadne's love,
But Giovanno did; come now to our father's castle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pardon me; there is a bar that does
Concern my life forbids you as a friend,
To think on going to any place
But to, the tailor's house, which is not far:
Come, as we go I will relate the cause.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sebastine is your page, and bound to follow,
Lead on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O noble temper I admire thee! may
The world bring forth such tailors every day. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter three tailors on a shop board.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.l: Come, come let's work;
For if my guesses point the right, we shan't
Work long.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: I care not how soon, for I have a notable
Stomach to bread.

sp.speaker: 2 Tay
sp.l: Dost hear, I suspect that courtier my master
Brought in last night, to be the King;
Which if it be bullies, all the bread in the
town shan't satisfy us, for we will eat
Cum privelegio.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Come let's have a device, a thing, a song boy

div.stage: The song.

sp.speaker: 1 Tay,
sp.l: 'Tis a merry life we live,
All our work is brought unto us;
Still are getting, never give;
For their clothes all men do woe us:
Yet unkind they blast our names,
With aspersions of dishonour:
For which we make bold with their dames,
When we take our measure on her.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Giovanno, and the old tailor,

sp.p: Old Tay. You see the life we live, cease.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: It is no news to me, I have been used to't.

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.l: Now for discovery, the King as yet
Is ignorant of your names, and shall be
Till your merits beg your pardon.
My lord you are for machvile; take this gown.

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.l: You in this French disguise for proud Philippa;
This is her garment. I hear the King, be gone:
The French man's folly sit upon your tongue. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the King, Evadne and Aurelia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Believe me tailor you have outstripped the court,
For such perfections lives not everywhere ,
Nature was vexed as she's a very shrew,
She made all others in an angry mood;
These only she can boast for masterpieces:
the rest want something or in mind or form,
These are precisely made: a critic jury,
Of cavilling arts cannot condemn a scruple.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But that your entrance in this formal speech
Betrayed you are a courtier; I had been angry
At your rank flattery.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: Sir, she has spoke my meaning.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Friend, what are those beauties called?Aside.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are they oracle, or is the knowledge fatal?
But that I know thy faith, this denial
Would conjure a suspicion in my breast;
Use thy prerogative, 'tis thy own house
In which you are a King; and I your guest.
Come ladies. Exeunt.
sp.stage: Enter Antonio disguised like a physician.
sp.l: This habit will do well, and less suspected;
Rapt i'this cover lives a kingdom's plague,
They kill with licence; Machvile's proud dame
'Tis famed is sick, upon my soul, howe'er
Her health may be the aguesh commons cry;
She's a disease they groan for: this disguise
Shall sift her ebon soul, and if she be
Infectious, like a migraine, or rot limb ▪
The sword of justice must divide the joint
That holds her to the states endangered body.
She comes.

div.stage: Enter Machvile with Auristella leaning on his arm, with two servants.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Look up my Auristella;
Better the sun forsake his course to bless,
with his continuing beams the antipodes,
And we grovel for ever in eternal night,
Than death eclipse thy rich and stronger light.
Seek some physician, horror to my soul, she faints;
I'd rather lose the issue of my hopes, than Auristella.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The crown's enjoinment can yield no content,
Without the presence of my Auristilla.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Why stir you not? fetch me some skilful man,
My kingdom shall reward him; if his art
Chain her departing soul unto her flesh,
But for a day, till she be crowned a Queen:
Fly, bring him unto this walk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay,
Most honoured count, (Now for a forged linkAside.
Of flattery to chain me to his love;)
Having with studious care gone o'er the art
Folly terms magic, which more sublime souls
Skilled i'the stars, know is above that mischief;
I find you're born to be above vulgar greatness,
Even to a throne: but stay, let's fetch this lady.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: All greatness without her is slavery.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Godlike physician, I and all that's mine,
Will at thy feet offer a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Forefend it goodness; ay, nay all;
Ere many hours makes the now young day
A type of sparkling youth; shall on their knees
Pray for your highness.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Look up my Auristella, and be great;
Rise with the sun, but never to decline,

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Waked thee to be a Queen.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A Queen ▪ oh don't dissemble; you have robbed me
Of greater pleasure, than the fancied bliss
Elysium owns: oh for a pleasure real, that
Would appear in all unto my dream: that I may
Frown, and then kill; smile, and create again.
Were there a hell, as doting age would have,
To fright from lawless courses heed less youth:
For such a short lived happiness as that,
I would be lost unto eternity.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The day grows old in hours:
Come Auristella to the capital;
The graybeard senate shall on humble knees,
Pay a religious sacrifice of praise
Unto thy demi deity: the stars
Have in a general senate made thee Queen
Of this our world: great master of thy art,
Confirm my love.

sp.speaker: Mach
sp.l: Nay hear him love, believe me he's a man
That may be secretary to the gods;
He is alone in art, 'twere sin to name
A second; all are dunces to him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How easy is the faith of the ambitious.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Follow me to the counsel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Are you the man my husband speaks so high of?
Are you skilled i'the stars?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your habit says, or you abuse the custom,
You're a physician?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And d'ye find no let that stops my rising.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Away, your skill is dull, dull to derision.
There is a star fixed i'the heaven of greatness,
That sparkles with a rich and fresher light,
Than our sick and defective taper.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It may be so, the horiscope is troubled;

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Confusion take your horiscope and you.
Can you with all your art advise my fears,
how to confound this constellation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Death how she conjures;
Madam I must search into the planets.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Planet me no planets; be a physician,
And from your study of industrious poisons,
Fetch me your best experienced speedy one,
And bring it to me straight: what 'tis to do,
Like unresolved riddles hid from you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Planet said I; upon my life no planet
Is so swift as her never resting evil,
That's her tongue: well I'll not question
What the poisons for, if for herself,
The common hangman's eased the labour of a blow,
For if she live her head must certain off;
The poison I'll go get, and give it her,
Then to the King:
If Sebastiano's frenchified disguise
Purchase the like discovery, our eyes
Will be too scanty; we had need to be
All eye, to watch such haughty villainy. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Giovanno and Philippa.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Begare madam me make de gown so brave; oh, de hole vorle vorke be me patron, me ha' vorke for le grand Duchess le Shevere, le royne de Francia, Spanea de Angleter an all d'fine mademoiselles.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay monsieur to deprive desert of praise, is unknown language, troth I use it not ▪ nay it is very well.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Be me trot a madam never do ill, de English man do ill, de spanere do, de Dutch, de all do ill, but your franch man, and begare he do incomparable brave.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p:
Begare me no proud I'd vorle, me speak be me trot de trut, ang me no lie; metra madam begare you have de find bode a de vorle, oh de fine brave big ting me have ever
measure, me waire fit it so pat.

div.stage: Enter Raimond.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Welcome my lord,
Shall I still long, yet lose my longing still?
Is there no art to mount the lofty seat?
No engine that may make us ever great?
Must we be still styled subjects, and for fear
Our closest whispers reach the owing care,
Not trust the wind? Ray. Be calm my love,
Ha, who have we here an eves dropper.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Me signior, be povera i●nile homa a franch
A votre commandment.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Some happy genius does attend my wishes,
Or spirit like a page conducts unto me
The ministers, whose sweet must sent me easy.
Come hither French man, canst thou rule thy tongue?
Art not too much a woman?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: No begar me show something for de man.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Or canst thou be like a perverse on, profess doggedness?
Be as a dead man dumb, briefly be this:
A friend to France, and with a silent speed,
Post to our now approaching armed friends:
Tell them that Raimond e'er the hasty sand
Of a short hour be spent, shall be impaled,
And on his brow a deputy for France,
Support a golden wreath of kingly cares:
Bid 'em make haste to pluck my partner down
Into his grave; be gone, as thou nursest
In thy breast thoughts that do thirst
For nobleness: be secret and thou'rt made;
If not, thou'rt nothing. Mark, 'tis Raimond says it:
And as I live, I breathe not, if my deeds
Appear not in a horror above my words.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p:
Begar me no nedde threaten; me be as close to your secret, or my lady's secrets as de skin to de flesh; de flesh to
de bone: if me tell me de — vat, de ye call de modero de dog, de bich; call me de son o de bich.

div.stage: Enter Fulgentio.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Count Machvile waits your honour i'th hall.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Do't, and be more than common in our favour;
Here take this ring for thy more credit:
Farewell, be quick and secret. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Folly go from my tongue, the French so nigh,
And thou half ruined Spain, so wretchedly provided;
Strange, yet not, all countries have bred monsters:
'Tis a proverb as plain as true, and aged as 'tis both:
One tainted sheep mares a whole flock.
Machvile that tainted beast, whose spreading ills
Infecteth all; and by infecting kills.
I'll to the franch, what he intends to be
Our ruin; shall confound their villainy. Exit.

div.head: Act fifth.
Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter the King, Antonio, old tailor, Evadne, Aurelia, the King and Antonio whisper.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For this discovery be still Antonio,
The frowning law, may with a furrowed face
Hereafter look upon; but ne'er shall touch
They condemned body. Here from a King's hand,
Take thy Aurelia; our command shall smooth
The rising billows of her father's rage,
And charm it to a calm: let one be sent
To certify our pleasure, we would see him.

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.p: Your graces will shall be in all obeyed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thy loyal love, makes thy King poor.

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.l: Let not your judgement, royal sir, be questioned,
To term that love, was but a subject's duty. Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You sent the poison, did you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and it like your grace, the apothecary
Called it a strong provocative to madness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Did not he question what you used it for?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O my disguise saved him that labour, sir,
My habit, that was more physician than myself,
Told him 'twas to dispatch some property
That had been tortured with five thousand drugs
To try experiment: another man
Shan't buy the quantity of so much ratsbane
Shall kill a flea, but shall be had forsooth
Before a justice, be questioned; nay, perhaps
Confined to peep throw an iron grate:
When your physician may poison, who
Not, cum privilegio: it is his trade.

div.stage: Enter Giovanno.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Peace my Avadne, the King must not yet know me.

sp.speaker: Evad.
sp.p: My brother has already made you known.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Sabastiano, to be still a King
Of universal Spain, without a rival?
Yes, it does please me, and you ministers
Of my still growing greatness, shall ere long
Find I am pleased with you, the boldly durst
Pluck from the fixed arm of sleeping justice
Her long sheathed sword; and whet the rusty blade
Upon the bones of Machville, and his
Confederate rebels.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That my lord is yet to do, let him mount higher.
That his fall may be too deep for a resurrection;
They're gone to the great hall, whither wilt please your
grace disguised to go, your person by our care shall be
Secure. Their French troops I have sent as useless into
France, by virtue of Raimond's ring, which he gave
Me to bid the general by that token
To march to this city.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What say the colonels will they assist me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come then, let's go guarded, with such as you
'Twere sin to fear, were all the world untrue. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter tailors.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.p: Now for the credit of tailors.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: Nay, master and we do not act as they say,
With any players in the globe of the world,
Let us be baited like a bull for a company of
Strutting coxcombs: nay we can act I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.l: Well I must to the King; see you be perfect,
I'll move it to his highness. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Now my masters are we to do; d'ye mark me, do —

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: Do; what do? Act, act, you fool you, do said you, what do? you a player, you a plasterer, a mere dirt dauber; and not worthy to be mentioned with virmine, that exact actor: do, I am ashamed on't, fie.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: Well said Virmine, thou ticklest him i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Well play; we are to play a play.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: Play a play a play, ha, ha, ha; oh egregious nonsensical widgeon, thou shame to our cross-legged corporation; thou fellow of a sound, play a play; why forty pound golding of the beggar's theater speaks better, yet has a mark for the sage audience to exercise their dexterity, in throwing of rotten apples whilst my stout actor pockets, and then eats up the injury: play a play, it makes my worship laugh i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: To him Virmine, thou bit'st him i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Well, act a play before the King.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: To fret the French the more, we will act strange but true, or the straddling monsieur, with the Neopolitan gentleman between his legs.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: Oh giant of incomparable ignorance: that won't act well, ha, ha, that won't do well, you ass you.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: You bit him for saying do: virmine leave biting you'd best.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: What say you to our Spanish bilbo?

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: That he was a mad rascal to stab himself.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: No, no, let us act him.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.l: Who shall act the ghost.
3 why marry that will I, I virmine.
1 thou dost not look like a ghost.
3. A little player's deceit: flower will do't; mark me,
I can rehearse, mark me rehearse some:
When this eternal substance of the soul
Did live imprisoned in my wanton flesh,
I was a tailor in the court of Spain.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: Courtier Virmine in the court of Spain.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: Ay, there's a great many courtiers virmine indeed:
Those are they beg poor men's livings;
But I say, tailor vermin is a court Tailor.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: That will I:
Mark if I do not gape wider than the widest
Mouthed fowler of them all, hang me:
"Who calls Jeronimo from his naked bed: haugh!
Now for the passionate part —
" alas it is my son Horatio.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Very fine: but who shall act Horatio?

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: Ay, who shall do your son?

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.p: What do, do again: well I will act Horatio.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: Pray who is fitter to act the son, than the father
That begotten him.

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Who shall act prince Belthazer and the King?

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: I will do prince Belthazer too: and for the King
Who but I? which of you all has such a face for a King,
Or such a leg to trip up the heels of a traitor?

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: You will do all I think.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: Yes marry will I; who but virmine? yet I will
Leave all to play the King:
Pass by Jeronimo.

sp.speaker: 2 tailor
sp.p: Then you are for the King?

sp.speaker: 1 tailor
sp.p: Let's go seek our fellows, and to this gear.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.stage: A table and stools set. Enter brave,
sp.p: Men of our needful profession, that deal in such commodities as men's lives, had need to look about 'em be they traffic: I am to kill Raimond, the devils cozen germane, for he wears the same complexion: but there is a right devil that hath hired me, that's count Machvile. Good table conceal me, here will I wait my watchword: but stay, have I not forgotten it (Then) I then is my arm to enter. I hear them coming.

div.stage: Goes under the table.
Enter the King, Antonio, old tailor, Evadne, Aurelia, above. Machvile, Raimond, Philippa, Auristella, Giovanno, the colonels, with a guard below.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Well wrought poison, oh how joy swells me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You see my lord the poison is boxed up.Above.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Health waste upon this royal company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O no my lord, 'tis to the twins of treason:
Machvile, and Raymond.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I cannot stay; oh I am sick to death. Exit.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Or I'll ne'er trust poison more.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Pray seat yourselves
Gentlemen, though your deserts have meritThey sit above the table.
And your worths have deserved nobly;
But ingratitude, that should be banished
From a prince's breast, is Philip's favourite.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Philip traitor, why not King? I am so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Patience good my lord; I'll down. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: It lives too near him:
You that have ventured with expense of blood,
And danger of your lives, to rivet him
Unto his seat with peace: you that in war
He termed his atlases, and pressed with praises
Your brawny shoulders; called you his colossuses,
And said your looks frighted tall war
Out of his territories: now in peace,
The issue of your labour: this bad man,
Philip I mean, made of ingratitude,
Won't afford a name, that may distinguish
Your worthy selves from cowards:
Civet cats spotted with rat's dung,
Or a face like white broth, strewed o'er with currants
For a stirring caper, or itching dance; to
please my lady Vanity, shall be made
A smock knight.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Villain, must our disgrace mount thee?

sp.speaker: Aler.
sp.p: What means count Machvile? Enter Antonio below.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To be your King; fie on this circumstance,
My longing will not brook it: say,
Will you obey us as your Kings and Queens.Aside.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Confine yourselves, the King is within hearing; therefore make show of liking Machvile's plot: let him mount high, his fall will be the deeper: my life you shall be safe.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: If not we'll force you to't:
Speak French man, are our forces i'th city?

sp.speaker: Aler. Ful. Pan.
sp.l: We acknowledge you our King.
King more traitors.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Why then. The brave stabs Raymond.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Ha, from whence this sudden mischief?
Did you not see a hand armed with the fatal
Ruin of my life.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; lay hold on those French soldiers,
Away with them. Exeunt guard with the French colonels.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Wast thy plot Machvile? go laughing to thy grave.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Alas my lord is wounded. Stabs him.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Come hither French man, make a dying man
Bound to thy love; go to Philippa,
Sickly as she is bring her unto me;
Or my flying soul will not depart in peace else:
Prithee make haste: yet stay, I have not breath
To pay thy labour.
Shrink ye, you twin-born atlases, that bear
This my near ruined world; have you not strength
to bear a curse, whose breath may taint the air,
That this globe may feel a universal plague.
No, yet bear up, till with a vengeful eye
I outstare day, and from the dogged sky
Pluck my impartial star: oh, my blood
Is frozen in my veins — farewell revenge — me — dies.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: They condemn, and execute without a jury.

div.stage: Enter Philippa mad.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I come, I come; nay fly not, for by hell
I'll pluck thee by the beard, and drag thee thus
Out of thy fiery cave. Ha, on yonder hill
Stand troops of devils waiting for my soul:
But I'll deceive 'em, and instead of mine,
Send this same spotted tigers. Stabs Auristellae.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So, whilst they to hell
Are posting with their prize, I'll steal to heaven:
Wolf dost thou grin? ha, is my Raymond dead?
So ho, so ho: come back
You sooty fiends that have my Raymond's soul,
And lay it down, or I will force you do't:
No, won't you stir? by Styx I'll bait you for't:
Where is my crown? Philippa was a Queen,
Was she not ha? Why so, where is my crown:
Oh you have hid it — ha, waest thouOver throws the table.
That robbed Philippa of her Raymond's life?
Nay I will nip your wings, you shall not fly;
I'll pluck you by the guarded front: and thus
Sink you to hell before me. Stabs the brave.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What down, ho, ho, ho:
Laugh, laugh, you souls that fry in endless flames;
ha, whence this chillness — must I die — nay then,
I come, I come, nay weep not for I come:
Sleep injured shadow, oh death strikes dumb.Dies.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Machvile thy hand, I can't repent, farewell:
My burdened conscience sinks me down to hell. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: I cannot tarry long, farewell; we'll meet
Where we shall never part: if here be any
My life has injured, let your charity
Forgive declining Machvile: I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His penitence works strongly on my temper.
Of disguise, see falling count: Antonio forgives thee.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Antonio, oh my shame,
Can you whom I have injured most pardon my guilt?
Give me thy hand yet nearer, this embrace
Betray's thee to thy death: ha, ha, ha. Stabs him.
So weeps the Egyptian monster when it kills,
Washed in a flood of tears; couldst ever think
Machvile's repentance could come from his heart;
No, down colossus author of my sin,
And bear the burden mingled with thine own,Enter the King. Aur. Evad. old tay.
To finish thy damnation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Accursed villain, thou hast murdered him
That holds not one small drop of loyal blood:
But what is worth thy life.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Give him some air, the wound cannot be mortal.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Alas he faints, oh my Antonio:
Cursed Machvile, may thy soul —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace, peace Aurelia; be more merciful:
Men are apt to censure, and will condemn
Thy passion, call it madness, and say thou
Wantest religion: nay weep not sweet,
For every one must die: it was thy love,
For to deceive the law, and give me life:
But death you see has reached me, oh, I die;
Blood must have blood, so speaks the law of heaven:
I slew the governor, for which rash deed;
Heaven, fate, and man, thus make Antonio bleed. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Sleep, sleep great heart, thy virtue made me ill
Authors of vice, 'tis fit the vicious kill:
But yet forgive me, o, my great heart
Dissolves like snow, and lessons to a rheum,
Cold as the envious blasts of notherne wind:
World how I loved thee, 'twere a sin to boast;
Farewell, I now must leave thee; my life
Grows empty with my veins: I cannot stand, my breath
Is as my strength, weak; and both seized by death:
Farewell ambition catching at a crown,
Death tripped me up, and headlong threw me down. Dyes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So falls an exhalation from the sky,
And's never missed because unnatural;
A birth begotten by incorporate ill:
Whose usher to the gazing world is wonder.
Alas good man, thou'rt come unto a sight
Will try thy temper, whether joy or grief
Shall conquer most within thee; joy lies here
Scattered in many heaps: these when they lived,
Threatened to tear this balsam from our brow,
And rob our majesty of this elixir:Points to his crown.
Is't not my right? was not I heir to Spain?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You are our prince, and may you live
Long to enjoy your right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But now look here, 'tis plain grief has a hand
Harder than joy; it presseth out such tears.
Nay rise.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace not to think me
Contriver of Antonio's scape from death,
'Twas my disloyal daughter's breach of duty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Antonio was thy son, I sent for thee
for to confirm it, but he is dead:
Be merciful, and do not curse the hand
That gave it him, though it deserve it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O my griefs, are you not strong enough
To break my heart? pray tell me, tell me true;
Can it be thought a sin? or is it so,
By my own hand to ease my breast of woe?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Alas poor lady; rise, thy father's here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Look up Aurelia, ha, why do you kneel?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why she is not Aurelia, do not mock me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But he is Sebastiano and your son;
Late by our hand made happy by enjoying
The fair Evadne dead Antonio's sister:
For whose sake he became a tailor,
And so long lived in that mean disguise.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: My joy had been too great if he had lived,
The thrifty heavens mingle our sweets with gall;
Lest being glutted with excess of good,
We should forget the giver. Rise Sebastiano
With thy happy choice, mayst thou live crowned
With the enjoyment of those benefits,
My prayers shall beg for: rise Aurelio,
And in some place blessed with religious prayers,
Spend thy left remnant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You advise well: indeed it was a fault
To break the bonds of duty, and of law;
But love, oh love; thou whose all conquering power,
Builds castles on the hearts of easy maids,
And makes 'em strong unto attempt those dangers:
That but rehearsed before, would fright their souls
Into a jelly. Brother, I must leave you;
And father, when I send to you a note, that shall
Desire a yearly stipend to that holy place
My tired feet has found to rest them in;
Pray confirm it.
And now great King Aurelia begs of you,
To grace Antonio in the mournful march
Unto his grave, which be where you think fit:
We need not be interred both in one vault.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Blessed virgin, thy desires I will perform.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Then I leave you, my prayers shall still attend you
As I hope yours shall accompany me.
Father your blessing, and ere long expect
To hear where I am entertained a nun
Brother, and sister, to you both adieu;
Antonio dead, Aurelia marries new. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Farewell girl, when I remember thee,
The beads I drop shall be my tears. Enter Vermine in a cloak for the prologue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She's to all virgins a true mirror;
They that would behold true love, reflect on her:
There 'tis ingrossed.

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.p: The King is sad, you must not act.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: How? not act?
Shall not vermin act?

sp.speaker: Old tailor
sp.l: Yes you shall act, but not now;
The King is indisposed.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: Well then, some other time; I virmine
The King will act before the King.

sp.speaker: 3 tailor
sp.l: I'll muster up all the tailors in theThe King and Gio. whisper.
Town, and so tickle their sides.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.l: Nay thou'rt a right virmine, go be not
Troublesome. Exit Virmine.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Upon my truth and loyalty great King,
What they did was but feigned, merely words
Without a heart: 'twas by Antonio's counsel.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou art all truth: rise. The colonels kneel.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live King Philip in the calm of peace,
To exercise his regal clemency.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take up Antonio's body, and let the rest
find Christian burial: mercy befits a King,
Come trusty tailor,
And to all countries let swift fame report,
King Philip made a tailor's house his court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We can't enough pay thy alone deserts,
Kings may be poor, when subjects are like thee,
So fruitful in all loyal virtuous deeds:
March with the body we'll perform all rights,
Of sable ceremony: that done,
We'll to our court, since all our own is won.

div.stage: Exeunt.
